contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox royalty | type = monarch | name = Ecgfrith | succession = [[King of Mercia]] | image = | caption = | reign = July 796 – December 796 AD | predecessor = [[Offa of Mercia|Offa]] | successor = [[Coenwulf of Mercia|Cœnwulf]] | house = [[List of monarchs of Mercia|House of Mercia]] | spouse = | issue = | father = Offa | mother = [[Cynethryth]] | death_date = December 796 AD | burial = }} '''Ecgfrith''' was king of [[Mercia]] from July to December 796. He was the son of [[Offa of Mercia|Offa]], the greatest king of Mercia, and [[Cynethryth]].<ref name =BiogDic>{{cite encyclopedia|encyclopedia=A Biographical Dictionary of Dark Age Britain|editors=Ann Williams, Alfred P. Smyth, D. P. Kirby|author=Ann Williams|title=Ecgfrith king of Mercia|publisher=Seaby|year=1991|isbn=1 85264 047-2}}</ref> In 787, Ecgfrith had been consecrated king, the first known consecration of an English king, probably arranged by Offa in imitation of the consecration of [[Charlemagne]]'s sons by the pope in 781.<ref name =BiogDic/><ref>{{cite encyclopedia |first=S. E.|last =Kelly | publisher = Oxford University Press | encyclopedia= Oxford Dictionary of National Biography | title=Offa (d. 796), king of the Mercians | year = 2007 | url =http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/20567/52312?docPos=2 | accessdate=22 July 2012 |doi=10.1093/ref:odnb/52312 }} {{ODNBsub}}</ref> Ecgfrith was succeeded by a distant relative, [[Coenwulf of Mercia|Cœnwulf]], apparently because Offa had arranged the murder of nearer relatives in order to eliminate dynastic rivals. According to a contemporary letter from [[Alcuin of York]], an English deacon and scholar who spent over a decade at [[Charlemagne]]'s court as one of his chief advisors:<ref name=BEASE_24>Lapidge, "Alcuin of York", in Lapidge et al., "Encyclopaedia of Anglo-Saxon England", p. 24.</ref> :That most noble young man has not died for his sins, but the vengeance for the blood shed by the father has reached the son. For you know how much blood his father shed to secure the kingdom upon his son.<ref name =BiogDic/> Alcuin added: "This was not a strengthening of the kingdom, but its ruin."<ref name=EHD_786>Letter of Alcuin to Mercian ealdorman Osbert, tr. in Whitelock, ''English Historical Documents'', p. 787</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} ==See also== * [[Kings of Mercia family tree]] {{S-start}} {{s-reg|other}} {{succession box| before=[[Offa of Mercia|Offa]]| title=[[List of monarchs of Mercia|King of Mercia]]| years=796| after=[[Coenwulf of Mercia|Coenwulf]] }} {{S-end}} {{Kings of Mercia}} {{Persondata | name =Ecgfrith of Mercia | alternative names = | short description = | date of birth = | place of birth = | date of death = 796 | place of death = }} [[Category:796 deaths]] [[Category:Mercian monarchs]] [[Category:8th-century monarchs in Europe]] [[Category:8th-century English people]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] {{England-bio-stub}}
